issue.title: Dependency on Exexif
issue.body:
There appears to be a dependency on Exexif which is not declared in mix.exs (well it is but only under the `:ci` group)

Specifically
```
== Compilation error in file lib/lib_lat_lon/data/coords.ex ==
** (ArgumentError) could not load module Exexif due to reason :unavailable
    lib/lib_lat_lon/data/coords.ex:26: (module)
```

issue.title: Dependency on Exexif
issue.body:

```

comment.body:
Hi @atavistock, thanks for pointing this out.

There were some requests to amend the original `exexif` package, I provided the PR which has not been merged, so some people asked me to fork it and I did `nextexif`. Both might be used here, so one just needs to explicitly define a dependency.

I should have it clearly stated in docs and I will one day.

commits.message:
Attach error to state. (#27)

* Attach error to state.

When error happens on transit - it's logged on Finitomata level and "gone" afterwards.
This commit "attaches" transit error to FSM state. So it can be accessed and acted upon at `on_failure` callback.

* Update lib/finitomata.ex

Co-authored-by: Aleksei Matiushkin <aleksei.matiushkin@kantox.com>

* Fix state naming.

* Update test/support/modules.ex

Co-authored-by: Aleksei Matiushkin <aleksei.matiushkin@kantox.com>

* Change state.error to state.last_error.

`state.last_error` is a map now.
Additionally to error itself it holds state and event at which the error happened.

Co-authored-by: Aleksei Matiushkin <aleksei.matiushkin@kantox.com>

issue.body:
When error happens on transit - it's logged on Finitomata level and "gone" afterwards (pls, correct me if I'm wrong).
I think it would be useful to "attach" transit error to FSM state. So it can be accessed and acted upon at `on_failure` callback.

Don't hesitate to decline the pull request if you don't agree with this change :)

comment.body:
> we keep it as it is now, part of the state (as a `last_error`). Yes?

Almost, as a `%State{state | last_error: [state: state.current, event: event, error: err]}` _or_ as `%State{state | last_error: {state.current, event, err}}` which one you like more :)

issue.title: Attach error to state.
issue.body:
When error happens on transit - it's logged on Finitomata level and "gone" afterwards (pls, correct me if I'm wrong).
I think it would be useful to "attach" transit error to FSM state. So it can be accessed and acted upon at `on_failure` callback.

Don't hesitate to decline the pull request if you don't agree with this change :)

comment.body:
> But from your comment I understand now that it might not be the final state. Am I correct here? 

Yes. It would be called every time when the transition has not succeeded, not even only due to an exception raised, but also in cases when `on_transition/4` callback returned crap, or unreachable `to` state, or whatever.

> I would […] leave the cleaning up part for `on_failure/3` implementation.

No way, this callback is not intended to modify the state, it’s `on_failure(…) :: :ok`.

> I think the `[{transition(), reason}]` is good way to approach it. 

See below, TL;DR: I think we don’t need to keep a tail, the latest one would be enough, as `{from, event, reason}`.

> maybe even better would be to pass it to `safe_on_failure/4`?

Yes, but it’s a library and you know what people hate most in library adoption? When it changes the API out of the blue. We might go the long path, deprecating but still supporting `on_failure/3` till `v1.0.0`, but I don’t see it’s worth it.

> we can keep state cleaner (and even have an easier way to pattern match the error)

In the first place, one is still able to pattern match the error with `%State{error: %MyException}` directly in `on_failure/3`. Also, the error is surely part of the state. That said, I’d keep the only last error, and I’d rename the struct key to `last_error`. Analyzing several last errors nevertheless must be considered an antipattern, and the consumer of the library should workaround this in their code anyway.

> Also, if we pass only to on_failure (be it /3 or /4) - the replies for soft events (line 448) and `:continue` for ensure entry (line 455) will lack the error.

After the third rethought, I’d keep it everywhere (all three clauses of `cond/1`.) After all, the respective handler might analyze the error in the _previously failed_ attempts and act respectively.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -442,6 +443,7 @@ defmodule Finitomata do
           end
         else
           err ->
+            state = %State{state | error: err}
comment.body:
After another fresh look, I hesitate to say what would be better, to keep a stale error forever (current,) to clean it up right before line 420 or to pass it to `safe_on_failure/3` _only_.

Thoughts?

This should be clarified before we merge the code.

issue.title: renaming `Parser.Mermaid`
issue.body:
Related to #25 

Maybe it would be worth it to rename `Parser.Mermaid` to `Parser.Flowchart` or `Parser.MermaidFlowchart` or something like that?

I could go ahead and do it if you're okay with this.

comment.body:
Hi @egidijusz, thanks for having your hands dirty with this, I appreciate it.

I am strongly against _renaming_ because it breaks backward compatibility. But in general, you are absolutely right. So I’d go with allowing regular atoms in `use Finitomata` clause for predefined syntaxes instead.

That said, we allow `:"Elixir.Foo.Bar.Baz"` atoms for _custom_ syntaxes, or deprecated `Finitomata.{Mermaid, PlantUML}`, or `:state_diagram` and/or `:flowchart` for predefined ones. Also, we clean up the documentation, getting rid of any mention of deprecated `Finitomata.{Mermaid, PlantUML}`.

If it sounds OK, the PR would be strongly appreciated.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -442,20 +443,21 @@ defmodule Finitomata do
           end
         else
           err ->
+            state_with_error = struct(state, error: err)
comment.body:
`state` is already a struct, I’d prefer a more explicit
```suggestion
            state = %State{state | error: err}
```

Also, it’s still our old good state, no need to have a new name, _Elixir_ is not 100% _Erlang_.

review.body:
> Don’t hesitate to decline the pull request if you don't agree with this change :)

I maintain 10+ libs since 2010, I never hesitate to do anything :)

---

Jokes aside, I ❤ the idea.

What we need to do besides keeping the error, would be either clean it up _immediately after_ `on_failure/3` invocation or keep errors as a keyword list `[{transition(), reason}] when reason: any()`. Or, a keyword list of `[{state(), {transition(), reason}}]`, I am open to any suggestion.

The trick here would be to now overflood this list, so I’d go with a (maybe later configurable) number of last errors, let’s say, three.

WDYT?

issue.title: confusion about mermaid syntax
issue.body:
Hello,

this is not an issue per se, I'm just confused :)
Finitomata (as per README and code) supports two FSM description "syntaxes": [PlantUML](https://plantuml.com/en/state-diagram) and [Mermaid](https://mermaid.live) .
Where Mermaid looks like this:
```
s1 --> |to_s2| s2
s1 --> |to_s3| s3
```

But the actual Mermaid syntax (both on their [docs](https://mermaid-js.github.io/mermaid/#/stateDiagram) and [live editor](https://mermaid.live/edit#pako:eNpt0LEOwiAQBuBXITeadijdGJx0dHIUYy7l1KZSDFxNTNN3l1JqYuJN8PFD7hihcYZAQWBk2rV482jLl9S9iHXanEVZbkWohBLsLqFaPO4Ty8zyl-vMdWaZeH5MCddlrP_gWlCAJW-xNbGzcT7TwHeypEHFpUHfadD9FHPD08TG96Zl50Fd8RGoABzYHd99A4r9QGsoT_dNUbp0WOZP3zB9ANtOT2k)) is not like this.
It's like this (basically a PlantUML syntax):
```
    [*] --> s1 : to_s1
    s1 --> s2 : to_s2
    s1 --> s3 : to_s3
    s2 --> [*] : ok
    s3 --> [*] : ok
```

Also, Finitomata's Mermaid syntax actually does not work on Mermaid's live editor, [example here](https://mermaid.live/edit#pako:eNpljTEKwzAQBL9ybG0VsTsVrvKDtIJwWOfYYElBOgWC7b9HqVKkW4ZhdseUvMCiKKtcV35kDubVu0hULmTMSIeme-kPKn9waHBAhyA58OpbZf8qDrpIEAfbppeZ66YOLp5N5arp9o4TrOYqHerT_35hZ96KnB_p-zDn)


Hence my confusion. **Where does the Mermaid syntax comes from?** Is it older Mermaid version? Am I missing something obvious here? 


P.s. I do vaguely remember that Mermaid (years ago?) had different syntax for State diagrams that looked like `s1 --> |to_s2| s2`. But I'm not sure, might be confusing it with some other tool.

comment.body: I am closing this issue because it seems to be cleaned up. If you have some further questions, please don’t hesitate to reopen it.

issue.title: confusion about mermaid syntax
issue.body:
Hello,

this is not an issue per se, I'm just confused :)
Finitomata (as per README and code) supports two FSM description "syntaxes": [PlantUML](https://plantuml.com/en/state-diagram) and [Mermaid](https://mermaid.live) .
Where Mermaid looks like this:
```
s1 --> |to_s2| s2
s1 --> |to_s3| s3
```

But the actual Mermaid syntax (both on their [docs](https://mermaid-js.github.io/mermaid/#/stateDiagram) and [live editor](https://mermaid.live/edit#pako:eNpt0LEOwiAQBuBXITeadijdGJx0dHIUYy7l1KZSDFxNTNN3l1JqYuJN8PFD7hihcYZAQWBk2rV482jLl9S9iHXanEVZbkWohBLsLqFaPO4Ty8zyl-vMdWaZeH5MCddlrP_gWlCAJW-xNbGzcT7TwHeypEHFpUHfadD9FHPD08TG96Zl50Fd8RGoABzYHd99A4r9QGsoT_dNUbp0WOZP3zB9ANtOT2k)) is not like this.
It's like this (basically a PlantUML syntax):
```
    [*] --> s1 : to_s1
    s1 --> s2 : to_s2
    s1 --> s3 : to_s3
    s2 --> [*] : ok

Exactly. I [have updated docs](https://hexdocs.pm/finitomata/readme.html) to make it less confusing; it’s a shame I didn’t make it clear enough from scratch.

issue.title: Crash when parsing hyperlink
issue.body:
I see a crash when trying to parse hyperlink inside square brackets:

```
 [[TEST](https://foo.com)]
```


```
[error] GenServer #PID<0.1177.0> terminating
** (ArgumentError) errors were found at the given arguments:

  * 1st argument: not a bitstring

This typically happens when calling Kernel.byte_size/1 with an invalid argument or when performing binary construction or binary concatenation with <> and one of the arguments is not a binary
    :erlang.byte_size({:a, %{href: "https://foo.com"}, ["TEST"]})
```

Looks like the `content` [here](https://github.com/am-kantox/md/blob/master/lib/md/parser/engine.ex#L830) is:
```
{:a, %{href: "https://foo.com"}, ["TEST"]}
```
and not a string.

comment.body:
Thanks for this bug report, @chaitanyapandit!

The new version `0.9.4` is published. Please note, that if you want the leading bracket to be preserved in the result, it should be escaped:

```elixir
    assert [{:span, %{class: "empty-anchor"}, [{:a, %{href: "https://foo.com"}, ["TEST"]}, "]"]}] =
             Md.parse("[[TEST](https://foo.com)]").ast

    assert [{:p, nil, ["[", {:a, %{href: "https://foo.com"}, ["TEST"]}, "]"]}] =
             Md.parse("\\[[TEST](https://foo.com)]").ast
```

issue.title: Nested Tags
issue.body:
Trying to support nested tags in markdown, example: 
```
<dl>
    <dt>Title 1</dt>
    <dd>Description 1</dd>
    <dt>Title 2</dt>
    <dd>Description 2</dd>
</dl>
```

Doesn't seem to parse the closing `</dl>` properly:
```
[{:dl, nil, [{:dt, nil, ["Title 1"]}]}, {:dd, nil, ["Description 1"]}, {:dt, nil, ["Title 2"]}, {:dd, nil, ["Description 2"]}, {:p, nil, ["</dl>"]}]
```

My parser syntax contains:
```
...
tag: [
      {"dl", %{}},
      {"dt", %{}},
      {"dd", %{}}
    ]
...
```

comment.body:
> if I could use the tags specified in GFM

The general answer to this question is **no, you cannot**, which means no promises were made on that topic and the last thing I am after is to support GFM or even CommonMark fully. 

> if I have newlines inside the tag

If you have two newlines inside anything (but triple-backticks,) they ultimately rewind the current state and start a new paragraph.

issue.title: Code block inside blockquote
issue.body:
When parsing code block (pre) inside blockquote with the following markdown:

```
> ```a```
```
The expected result is:
> ```a```

But the parsed `ast` is:
```
[{:blockquote, nil, [{:code, %{class: "code-inline"}, []}, {:code, %{class: "code-inline"}, ["f"]}, {:code, %{class: "code-inline"}, []}]}]
```

which makes it appear like (3 inline code inside blockquote)
> ` ` `a` ` `

comment.body:
The solution chosen: _all_ empty tags save for listed explicitly as `empty_tags` in `syntax` receive `class: "empty-tag"` attribute. To suppress empty tags from showing up in the resulting _HTML_, use the respective _CSS_ selector to hide them.

> Package published to https://hex.pm/packages/md/0.9.3
> (88a6265b813e8995a30f69fb6cfa988a17e5d49fc1c42c76635b196b4af4aec4)

comment.body:
> we keep it as it is now, part of the state (as a `last_error`). Yes?

Almost, as a `%State{state | last_error: [state: state.current, event: event, error: err]}` _or_ as `%State{state | last_error: {state.current, event, err}}` which one you like more :)

issue.title: Attach error to state.
issue.body:
When error happens on transit - it's logged on Finitomata level and "gone" afterwards (pls, correct me if I'm wrong).
I think it would be useful to "attach" transit error to FSM state. So it can be accessed and acted upon at `on_failure` callback.

Don't hesitate to decline the pull request if you don't agree with this change :)

comment.body:
> But from your comment I understand now that it might not be the final state. Am I correct here? 

Yes. It would be called every time when the transition has not succeeded, not even only due to an exception raised, but also in cases when `on_transition/4` callback returned crap, or unreachable `to` state, or whatever.

> I would […] leave the cleaning up part for `on_failure/3` implementation.

No way, this callback is not intended to modify the state, it’s `on_failure(…) :: :ok`.

> I think the `[{transition(), reason}]` is good way to approach it. 

See below, TL;DR: I think we don’t need to keep a tail, the latest one would be enough, as `{from, event, reason}`.

> maybe even better would be to pass it to `safe_on_failure/4`?

Yes, but it’s a library and you know what people hate most in library adoption? When it changes the API out of the blue. We might go the long path, deprecating but still supporting `on_failure/3` till `v1.0.0`, but I don’t see it’s worth it.

> we can keep state cleaner (and even have an easier way to pattern match the error)

In the first place, one is still able to pattern match the error with `%State{error: %MyException}` directly in `on_failure/3`. Also, the error is surely part of the state. That said, I’d keep the only last error, and I’d rename the struct key to `last_error`. Analyzing several last errors nevertheless must be considered an antipattern, and the consumer of the library should workaround this in their code anyway.

> Also, if we pass only to on_failure (be it /3 or /4) - the replies for soft events (line 448) and `:continue` for ensure entry (line 455) will lack the error.

After the third rethought, I’d keep it everywhere (all three clauses of `cond/1`.) After all, the respective handler might analyze the error in the _previously failed_ attempts and act respectively.

issue.title: renaming `Parser.Mermaid`
issue.body:
Related to #25 

Maybe it would be worth it to rename `Parser.Mermaid` to `Parser.Flowchart` or `Parser.MermaidFlowchart` or something like that?

I could go ahead and do it if you're okay with this.

comment.body:
Hi @egidijusz, thanks for having your hands dirty with this, I appreciate it.

I am strongly against _renaming_ because it breaks backward compatibility. But in general, you are absolutely right. So I’d go with allowing regular atoms in `use Finitomata` clause for predefined syntaxes instead.

That said, we allow `:"Elixir.Foo.Bar.Baz"` atoms for _custom_ syntaxes, or deprecated `Finitomata.{Mermaid, PlantUML}`, or `:state_diagram` and/or `:flowchart` for predefined ones. Also, we clean up the documentation, getting rid of any mention of deprecated `Finitomata.{Mermaid, PlantUML}`.

If it sounds OK, the PR would be strongly appreciated.

issue.title: confusion about mermaid syntax
issue.body:
Hello,

this is not an issue per se, I'm just confused :)
Finitomata (as per README and code) supports two FSM description "syntaxes": [PlantUML](https://plantuml.com/en/state-diagram) and [Mermaid](https://mermaid.live) .
Where Mermaid looks like this:
```
s1 --> |to_s2| s2
s1 --> |to_s3| s3
```

But the actual Mermaid syntax (both on their [docs](https://mermaid-js.github.io/mermaid/#/stateDiagram) and [live editor](https://mermaid.live/edit#pako:eNpt0LEOwiAQBuBXITeadijdGJx0dHIUYy7l1KZSDFxNTNN3l1JqYuJN8PFD7hihcYZAQWBk2rV482jLl9S9iHXanEVZbkWohBLsLqFaPO4Ty8zyl-vMdWaZeH5MCddlrP_gWlCAJW-xNbGzcT7TwHeypEHFpUHfadD9FHPD08TG96Zl50Fd8RGoABzYHd99A4r9QGsoT_dNUbp0WOZP3zB9ANtOT2k)) is not like this.
It's like this (basically a PlantUML syntax):
```
    [*] --> s1 : to_s1
    s1 --> s2 : to_s2
    s1 --> s3 : to_s3
    s2 --> [*] : ok
    s3 --> [*] : ok
```

Also, Finitomata's Mermaid syntax actually does not work on Mermaid's live editor, [example here](https://mermaid.live/edit#pako:eNpljTEKwzAQBL9ybG0VsTsVrvKDtIJwWOfYYElBOgWC7b9HqVKkW4ZhdseUvMCiKKtcV35kDubVu0hULmTMSIeme-kPKn9waHBAhyA58OpbZf8qDrpIEAfbppeZ66YOLp5N5arp9o4TrOYqHerT_35hZ96KnB_p-zDn)


Hence my confusion. **Where does the Mermaid syntax comes from?** Is it older Mermaid version? Am I missing something obvious here? 


P.s. I do vaguely remember that Mermaid (years ago?) had different syntax for State diagrams that looked like `s1 --> |to_s2| s2`. But I'm not sure, might be confusing it with some other tool.

comment.body: I am closing this issue because it seems to be cleaned up. If you have some further questions, please don’t hesitate to reopen it.

issue.title: Crash when parsing hyperlink
issue.body:
I see a crash when trying to parse hyperlink inside square brackets:

```
 [[TEST](https://foo.com)]
```


```
[error] GenServer #PID<0.1177.0> terminating
** (ArgumentError) errors were found at the given arguments:

  * 1st argument: not a bitstring

This typically happens when calling Kernel.byte_size/1 with an invalid argument or when performing binary construction or binary concatenation with <> and one of the arguments is not a binary
    :erlang.byte_size({:a, %{href: "https://foo.com"}, ["TEST"]})
```

Looks like the `content` [here](https://github.com/am-kantox/md/blob/master/lib/md/parser/engine.ex#L830) is:
```
{:a, %{href: "https://foo.com"}, ["TEST"]}
```
and not a string.

comment.body:
Thanks for this bug report, @chaitanyapandit!

The new version `0.9.4` is published. Please note, that if you want the leading bracket to be preserved in the result, it should be escaped:

```elixir
    assert [{:span, %{class: "empty-anchor"}, [{:a, %{href: "https://foo.com"}, ["TEST"]}, "]"]}] =
             Md.parse("[[TEST](https://foo.com)]").ast

    assert [{:p, nil, ["[", {:a, %{href: "https://foo.com"}, ["TEST"]}, "]"]}] =
             Md.parse("\\[[TEST](https://foo.com)]").ast
```

issue.title: Nested Tags
issue.body:
Trying to support nested tags in markdown, example: 
```
<dl>
    <dt>Title 1</dt>
    <dd>Description 1</dd>
    <dt>Title 2</dt>
    <dd>Description 2</dd>
</dl>
```

Doesn't seem to parse the closing `</dl>` properly:
```
[{:dl, nil, [{:dt, nil, ["Title 1"]}]}, {:dd, nil, ["Description 1"]}, {:dt, nil, ["Title 2"]}, {:dd, nil, ["Description 2"]}, {:p, nil, ["</dl>"]}]
```

My parser syntax contains:
```
...
tag: [
      {"dl", %{}},
      {"dt", %{}},
      {"dd", %{}}
    ]
...
```

comment.body:
> if I could use the tags specified in GFM

The general answer to this question is **no, you cannot**, which means no promises were made on that topic and the last thing I am after is to support GFM or even CommonMark fully. 

> if I have newlines inside the tag

If you have two newlines inside anything (but triple-backticks,) they ultimately rewind the current state and start a new paragraph.

issue.title: Code block inside blockquote
issue.body:
When parsing code block (pre) inside blockquote with the following markdown:

```
> ```a```
```
The expected result is:
> ```a```

But the parsed `ast` is:
```
[{:blockquote, nil, [{:code, %{class: "code-inline"}, []}, {:code, %{class: "code-inline"}, ["f"]}, {:code, %{class: "code-inline"}, []}]}]
```

which makes it appear like (3 inline code inside blockquote)
> ` ` `a` ` `

comment.body:
The solution chosen: _all_ empty tags save for listed explicitly as `empty_tags` in `syntax` receive `class: "empty-tag"` attribute. To suppress empty tags from showing up in the resulting _HTML_, use the respective _CSS_ selector to hide them.

> Package published to https://hex.pm/packages/md/0.9.3
> (88a6265b813e8995a30f69fb6cfa988a17e5d49fc1c42c76635b196b4af4aec4)

    <dd>Description 2</dd>
</dl>
```

Doesn't seem to parse the closing `</dl>` properly:
```
[{:dl, nil, [{:dt, nil, ["Title 1"]}]}, {:dd, nil, ["Description 1"]}, {:dt, nil, ["Title 2"]}, {:dd, nil, ["Description 2"]}, {:p, nil, ["</dl>"]}]
```

My parser syntax contains:
```
...
tag: [
      {"dl", %{}},
      {"dt", %{}},
      {"dd", %{}}
    ]
...
```

```
<dl>
    <dt>Title 1</dt>
    <dd>Description 1</dd>
    <dt>Title 2</dt>
    <dd>Description 2</dd>
</dl>
```

Doesn't seem to parse the closing `</dl>` properly:
```
[{:dl, nil, [{:dt, nil, ["Title 1"]}]}, {:dd, nil, ["Description 1"]}, {:dt, nil, ["Title 2"]}, {:dd, nil, ["Description 2"]}, {:p, nil, ["</dl>"]}]
```

My parser syntax contains:
```
...
tag: [
      {"dl", %{}},
      {"dt", %{}},
      {"dd", %{}}
    ]
...
```

issue.title: Nested Tags
issue.body:
Trying to support nested tags in markdown, example: 
```
<dl>
    <dt>Title 1</dt>
    <dd>Description 1</dd>
    <dt>Title 2</dt>
    <dd>Description 2</dd>
</dl>
```

Doesn't seem to parse the closing `</dl>` properly:
```
[{:dl, nil, [{:dt, nil, ["Title 1"]}]}, {:dd, nil, ["Description 1"]}, {:dt, nil, ["Title 2"]}, {:dd, nil, ["Description 2"]}, {:p, nil, ["</dl>"]}]
```

My parser syntax contains:
```
...
tag: [
      {"dl", %{}},
      {"dt", %{}},
      {"dd", %{}}
    ]
...
```

comment.body:
@chaitanyapandit thanks for reporting, this looks like a bug, but I honestly don’t pay much attention to embedded _HTML_ because it’s definitely not what I want to fully support. At the moment, `md` does not support attributes for tags and the priority of that is low.

I have plans to support data lists natively, though. Anyway, this should be ready to fix and I’ll most likely do.

issue.title: Code block inside blockquote
issue.body:
When parsing code block (pre) inside blockquote with the following markdown:

```
> ```a```
```
The expected result is:
> ```a```

But the parsed `ast` is:
```
[{:blockquote, nil, [{:code, %{class: "code-inline"}, []}, {:code, %{class: "code-inline"}, ["f"]}, {:code, %{class: "code-inline"}, []}]}]
```

which makes it appear like (3 inline code inside blockquote)
> ` ` `a` ` `

comment.body:
I am not sure why would you expect the code block to be understood inside a block quote. What we should probably do, is to validate the content of the inline-block is empty and kinda discard it then.

For reference, here on GH, the triple-quote inside block quote would look like:

> ```a```

issue.body:
When error happens on transit - it's logged on Finitomata level and "gone" afterwards (pls, correct me if I'm wrong).
I think it would be useful to "attach" transit error to FSM state. So it can be accessed and acted upon at `on_failure` callback.

Don't hesitate to decline the pull request if you don't agree with this change :)

comment.body:
> we keep it as it is now, part of the state (as a `last_error`). Yes?

Almost, as a `%State{state | last_error: [state: state.current, event: event, error: err]}` _or_ as `%State{state | last_error: {state.current, event, err}}` which one you like more :)

issue.title: Attach error to state.
issue.body:
When error happens on transit - it's logged on Finitomata level and "gone" afterwards (pls, correct me if I'm wrong).
I think it would be useful to "attach" transit error to FSM state. So it can be accessed and acted upon at `on_failure` callback.

Don't hesitate to decline the pull request if you don't agree with this change :)

comment.body:
> But from your comment I understand now that it might not be the final state. Am I correct here? 

Yes. It would be called every time when the transition has not succeeded, not even only due to an exception raised, but also in cases when `on_transition/4` callback returned crap, or unreachable `to` state, or whatever.

> I would […] leave the cleaning up part for `on_failure/3` implementation.

No way, this callback is not intended to modify the state, it’s `on_failure(…) :: :ok`.

> I think the `[{transition(), reason}]` is good way to approach it. 

See below, TL;DR: I think we don’t need to keep a tail, the latest one would be enough, as `{from, event, reason}`.

> maybe even better would be to pass it to `safe_on_failure/4`?

Yes, but it’s a library and you know what people hate most in library adoption? When it changes the API out of the blue. We might go the long path, deprecating but still supporting `on_failure/3` till `v1.0.0`, but I don’t see it’s worth it.

> we can keep state cleaner (and even have an easier way to pattern match the error)

In the first place, one is still able to pattern match the error with `%State{error: %MyException}` directly in `on_failure/3`. Also, the error is surely part of the state. That said, I’d keep the only last error, and I’d rename the struct key to `last_error`. Analyzing several last errors nevertheless must be considered an antipattern, and the consumer of the library should workaround this in their code anyway.

> Also, if we pass only to on_failure (be it /3 or /4) - the replies for soft events (line 448) and `:continue` for ensure entry (line 455) will lack the error.

After the third rethought, I’d keep it everywhere (all three clauses of `cond/1`.) After all, the respective handler might analyze the error in the _previously failed_ attempts and act respectively.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -442,6 +443,7 @@ defmodule Finitomata do
           end
         else
           err ->
+            state = %State{state | error: err}
comment.body:
After another fresh look, I hesitate to say what would be better, to keep a stale error forever (current,) to clean it up right before line 420 or to pass it to `safe_on_failure/3` _only_.

Thoughts?

This should be clarified before we merge the code.

issue.title: renaming `Parser.Mermaid`
issue.body:
Related to #25 

Maybe it would be worth it to rename `Parser.Mermaid` to `Parser.Flowchart` or `Parser.MermaidFlowchart` or something like that?

I could go ahead and do it if you're okay with this.

comment.body:
Hi @egidijusz, thanks for having your hands dirty with this, I appreciate it.

I am strongly against _renaming_ because it breaks backward compatibility. But in general, you are absolutely right. So I’d go with allowing regular atoms in `use Finitomata` clause for predefined syntaxes instead.

That said, we allow `:"Elixir.Foo.Bar.Baz"` atoms for _custom_ syntaxes, or deprecated `Finitomata.{Mermaid, PlantUML}`, or `:state_diagram` and/or `:flowchart` for predefined ones. Also, we clean up the documentation, getting rid of any mention of deprecated `Finitomata.{Mermaid, PlantUML}`.

If it sounds OK, the PR would be strongly appreciated.

The trick here would be to now overflood this list, so I’d go with a (maybe later configurable) number of last errors, let’s say, three.

WDYT?

issue.title: confusion about mermaid syntax
issue.body:
Hello,

this is not an issue per se, I'm just confused :)
Finitomata (as per README and code) supports two FSM description "syntaxes": [PlantUML](https://plantuml.com/en/state-diagram) and [Mermaid](https://mermaid.live) .
Where Mermaid looks like this:
```
s1 --> |to_s2| s2
s1 --> |to_s3| s3
```

But the actual Mermaid syntax (both on their [docs](https://mermaid-js.github.io/mermaid/#/stateDiagram) and [live editor](https://mermaid.live/edit#pako:eNpt0LEOwiAQBuBXITeadijdGJx0dHIUYy7l1KZSDFxNTNN3l1JqYuJN8PFD7hihcYZAQWBk2rV482jLl9S9iHXanEVZbkWohBLsLqFaPO4Ty8zyl-vMdWaZeH5MCddlrP_gWlCAJW-xNbGzcT7TwHeypEHFpUHfadD9FHPD08TG96Zl50Fd8RGoABzYHd99A4r9QGsoT_dNUbp0WOZP3zB9ANtOT2k)) is not like this.
It's like this (basically a PlantUML syntax):
```
    [*] --> s1 : to_s1
    s1 --> s2 : to_s2
    s1 --> s3 : to_s3
    s2 --> [*] : ok
    s3 --> [*] : ok
```

Also, Finitomata's Mermaid syntax actually does not work on Mermaid's live editor, [example here](https://mermaid.live/edit#pako:eNpljTEKwzAQBL9ybG0VsTsVrvKDtIJwWOfYYElBOgWC7b9HqVKkW4ZhdseUvMCiKKtcV35kDubVu0hULmTMSIeme-kPKn9waHBAhyA58OpbZf8qDrpIEAfbppeZ66YOLp5N5arp9o4TrOYqHerT_35hZ96KnB_p-zDn)


Hence my confusion. **Where does the Mermaid syntax comes from?** Is it older Mermaid version? Am I missing something obvious here? 


P.s. I do vaguely remember that Mermaid (years ago?) had different syntax for State diagrams that looked like `s1 --> |to_s2| s2`. But I'm not sure, might be confusing it with some other tool.

issue.title: Crash when parsing hyperlink
issue.body:
I see a crash when trying to parse hyperlink inside square brackets:

```
 [[TEST](https://foo.com)]
```


```
[error] GenServer #PID<0.1177.0> terminating
** (ArgumentError) errors were found at the given arguments:

  * 1st argument: not a bitstring

This typically happens when calling Kernel.byte_size/1 with an invalid argument or when performing binary construction or binary concatenation with <> and one of the arguments is not a binary
    :erlang.byte_size({:a, %{href: "https://foo.com"}, ["TEST"]})
```

Looks like the `content` [here](https://github.com/am-kantox/md/blob/master/lib/md/parser/engine.ex#L830) is:
```
{:a, %{href: "https://foo.com"}, ["TEST"]}
```
and not a string.

comment.body:
Thanks for this bug report, @chaitanyapandit!

The new version `0.9.4` is published. Please note, that if you want the leading bracket to be preserved in the result, it should be escaped:

```elixir
    assert [{:span, %{class: "empty-anchor"}, [{:a, %{href: "https://foo.com"}, ["TEST"]}, "]"]}] =
             Md.parse("[[TEST](https://foo.com)]").ast

    assert [{:p, nil, ["[", {:a, %{href: "https://foo.com"}, ["TEST"]}, "]"]}] =
             Md.parse("\\[[TEST](https://foo.com)]").ast
```

issue.title: Nested Tags
issue.body:
Trying to support nested tags in markdown, example: 
```
<dl>
    <dt>Title 1</dt>
    <dd>Description 1</dd>
    <dt>Title 2</dt>
    <dd>Description 2</dd>
</dl>
```

Doesn't seem to parse the closing `</dl>` properly:
```
[{:dl, nil, [{:dt, nil, ["Title 1"]}]}, {:dd, nil, ["Description 1"]}, {:dt, nil, ["Title 2"]}, {:dd, nil, ["Description 2"]}, {:p, nil, ["</dl>"]}]
```

My parser syntax contains:
```
...
tag: [
      {"dl", %{}},
      {"dt", %{}},
      {"dd", %{}}
    ]
...
```

comment.body:
> if I could use the tags specified in GFM

The general answer to this question is **no, you cannot**, which means no promises were made on that topic and the last thing I am after is to support GFM or even CommonMark fully. 

> if I have newlines inside the tag

If you have two newlines inside anything (but triple-backticks,) they ultimately rewind the current state and start a new paragraph.

issue.title: Code block inside blockquote
issue.body:
When parsing code block (pre) inside blockquote with the following markdown:

```
> ```a```
```
The expected result is:
> ```a```

But the parsed `ast` is:
```
[{:blockquote, nil, [{:code, %{class: "code-inline"}, []}, {:code, %{class: "code-inline"}, ["f"]}, {:code, %{class: "code-inline"}, []}]}]
```

which makes it appear like (3 inline code inside blockquote)
> ` ` `a` ` `

comment.body:
The solution chosen: _all_ empty tags save for listed explicitly as `empty_tags` in `syntax` receive `class: "empty-tag"` attribute. To suppress empty tags from showing up in the resulting _HTML_, use the respective _CSS_ selector to hide them.

> Package published to https://hex.pm/packages/md/0.9.3
> (88a6265b813e8995a30f69fb6cfa988a17e5d49fc1c42c76635b196b4af4aec4)

comment.body:
@chaitanyapandit thanks for reporting, this looks like a bug, but I honestly don’t pay much attention to embedded _HTML_ because it’s definitely not what I want to fully support. At the moment, `md` does not support attributes for tags and the priority of that is low.

I have plans to support data lists natively, though. Anyway, this should be ready to fix and I’ll most likely do.
